[http://ubc.ca/ ubc.ca] |logo = }} The 'University of British Columbia'
(commonly referred to as 'UBC') is a public research university located in
British Columbia, Canada. Its two main campuses are located in Vancouver and
Kelowna. The Vancouver campus is located within the University Endowment Lands,
about from Downtown Vancouver. A satellite campus is located
at Robson Street in Vancouver's city centre. The Kelowna
campus is located in the Okanagan Valley.

The University of British Columbia is ranked second in Canada and 30th
worldwide in the [[Times Higher Education]] rankings, 39th worldwide in the
[[Academic Ranking of World Universities]], and 8th overall in
[[Newsweek]] 's ranking of top universities outside of the
United States. In 2011 UBC reported the highest entrance
requirements for undergraduate admission in Canada. UBC faculty,
alumni, and researchers have won seven Nobel Prizes, 67 Rhodes Scholarships, 64
Olympic medals, and alumni include two Canadian prime ministers.

A corporation by the name of The University of British Columbia was first
incorporated April 26, 1890. 53 Vict. Cap. 48 Subsequent enactments
culminating on March 7, 1908 8 Ed. 7 cap. 53 with another University
Act gave the University its current form. The first day of lectures was
September 30, 1915, and lectures began at the new Point Grey campus on September
22, 1925. UBC's enabling legislation are the University
Act [http://www.qp.gov.bc.ca/statreg/stat/U/96468_01.htm University
Act] and the University Amendment Act, 2004. [http://www.legis.gov.bc.ca/37th5th/3rd_read/gov60-
3.htm University Amendment Act, 2004] The university is the oldest in
British Columbia and has the largest enrolment with over 54,000 students at its
Vancouver and Okanagan campuses combined. Dunae, P.A. (Ed.). (2003). 100 Years of Advanced Education, 1901â2001:
Higher Education and Advanced Teacher Training in British Columbia. Retrieved
June 1, 2008, from
http://records.viu.ca/homeroom/content/postsec/postsec.htm The university
library, which comprises 5.9 million books and journals, is the second-largest
research library in Canada.
